Ethiopla's ousted military trial for genocide of ruler Mengistu Halle Mariam and dozens of his aides ac- cused of crimes against humanity begins in Addis Ababa today in the absence of the ex-president. A special court is initially to try Colonel Mengistu, who fled into exile in Zimbabwe when he was toppled by rebels in May 1991, and 66 other officials from his regime. Among the main defendants who will actually appear in the Ethiopla's ousted military trial for genocide of ruler Mengistu Halle Mariam and dozens of his aides ac- cused of crimes against humanity begins in Addis Ababa today in the absence of the ex-president. A special court is initially to try Colonel Mengistu, who fled into exile in Zimbabwe when he was toppled by rebels in May 1991, and 66 other officials from his regime. Among the main defendants who will actually appear in the

open court charged with the murder of 1,823 opponents of the regime, is a former prime minister, Major Fekreselassie Wogdress. In all, the tribunal will try some 1,200 former civilian and military officials who worked for Mengistu. He took power in 1977 after winning control of the Derg, the junta that in 1974 ousted the "king of kings", the late Em- peror Hail Selaissie. Africa's first Nuremberg-style trial, which is expected to last for several months, has been inter- open court charged with the murder of 1,823 opponents of the regime, is a former prime minister, Major Fekreselassie Wogdress. nationally financed and took special prosecutor Ghirma Wakjira and his 40 assistants two years to prepare.
